title-group.subtitle: Evidence of a Gene × Environment Interaction

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: John Paul Wright is associate professor of criminal justice at the University of Cincinnati. His work focuses on the linkages between biological functioning and criminal and antisocial behavior.
Rebecca Schnupp is assistant professor of criminology at the University of Pennsylvania at Slippery Rock. Her research examines family factors associated with crime and other problem behaviors.
Kevin M. Beaver is associate professor of criminology at Florida State University. Dr.Beaver has published extensively on genetic and biological factors related to criminal conduct.

Matt Delisi is professor of criminal justice at Iowa State University. Dr.Delisi has an extensive research record that includes investigations into the causes and consequences of low self-control and criminal violence.
Michael Vaughn is associate professor of social work. Dr.Vaughn’s research has focused on juvenile psychopathy, substance abuse, and testing of biosocial models.

author-notes.corresp: John Paul Wright, School of Criminal Justice, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, USA. Email: john.wright@uc.edu

abstract.p: Maternal negativity has been consistently linked to a wide range of behavior problems in youth. Many of these problems are closely linked to low self-control. Even so, it is clear that not all youth exposed to maternal negativity show high levels of low self-control. Using direct measures of dopamine genes, we explore the extent to which dopamine genes are associated with variation in low self-control when accompanied by high and low levels of maternal negativity. Our results provide considerable evidence of a Gene × Enviornment interaction and may help to better specify which youth are likely to demonstrate low self-control when faced with stressful stimuli.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is a growing recognition that children exposed to difficult and stressful family environments are differentially affected by those environments (Belsky & Beaver, 2011). Some children, for example, appear resilient to harsh parenting techniques, to parental abuse and neglect, and to a full range of familial risk factors (Jaffee, Moffitt, Caspi, Taylor, & Arseneault, 2002). Others, however, appear to be adversely affected by these influences. Those that are adversely affected generally show a diverse array of problem behavior, including early onset drug use, delinquency, and failing out of school. Many of these problem behaviors are closely linked to deficiencies in self-control. Differences in self-control between youths may thus be a key factor in understanding why children are differentially affected by their rearing environment.

Substantial evidence implicates low self-control in the etiology of a range of problem behaviors (Cauffman, Steinberg, & Piquero, 2005; Gibson & Wright, 2001; Piquero & Tibbetts, 1996; Schoepfer & Piquero, 2006). The evidence is consistent, reliable, and by social science standards, impressive. However, the origins of self-control remain in empirical and theoretical dispute (Wright & Beaver, 2005). Gottfredson and Hirschi’s (1990) original formulation of self-control theory explicitly linked variation in specific parenting behaviors to the development of self-control in offspring. These behaviors are by now well known to most criminologists. Parents must, according to Gottfredson and Hirschi (1990), supervise their children, recognize their children’s deviant behavior, and respond in ways that limit misbehavior in the future.

A range of empirical studies have explored the connection between parenting behaviors and offspring self-control (Gibbs, Giever, & Martin, 1998; Perrone, Sullivan, Pratt, & Margaryan, 2004; Pratt, Turner, & Piquero, 2004; Unnever, Cullen, & Pratt, 2003). In general, these studies provide tentative evidence of a possible causal connection between parental socialization efforts and the development of self-control in youth. Even so, these studies are limited by at least two issues. First, theories that isolate parental socialization efforts as the causal mechanisms associated with variation in child traits and behaviors tend to overlook differences between children in their susceptibility to parental socialization efforts. These theories assume that children within the same household are uniformly accommodating to parental efforts. Individual youths, however, vary in their susceptibility to positive and negative environmental stimuli. Genes appear to be one of several variables that act to condition or modify individual responses to environmental stimuli (Belsky, 1997a; Ellis, 2011). Differential responses, rooted in genetic differences, to similar environmental contingencies are referred to as Gene × Environment interactions (Rutter, 2006, 2007). Recent evidence has found that children with certain genotypes respond differentially to child abuse (Caspi et al., 2002), to economic deprivation (Kim-Cohen, Moffitt, Caspi, & Taylor, 2004), to corporal punishment (Jaffee, Caspi, Moffitt, Polo-Tomas, et al., 2004), and to parental separation (O’Connor, Caspi, DeFries, & Plomin, 2003).

Second, the entanglement of shared and nonshared genetic influences by individual members within each family, confounds correlations between parenting and offspring traits and behaviors (Boivin et al., 2005; Burt, McGue, Iacono, & Krueger, 2006; Jaffee et al., 2005). For example, children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are significantly more likely to have parents with ADHD (Barkley, 1997a, b). According to several studies, including neuroimaging studies, ADHD is primarily a brain-based disorder caused by genetic influences (National Institute of Mental Health, 2003; Rowe et al., 1998; Smalley et al., 1998; Swanson et al., 1998) and, in certain instances, environmental insult from teratogens during fetal development (Button, 2007; McGloin, Pratt, & Piquero, 2006). Correlations linking the behavior of parents to the impulse control problems found in their children would, from a pure socialization perspective, constitute evidence linking poor parenting behavior to child conduct problems (Wright & Beaver, 2005). The recognition that parents and their offspring share genes, however, tempers such a claim.

This relates to self-control in the sense that there are strong reasons to suspect that genetic influences are deeply implicated in the development of self-regulation. A lengthy list of behavioral genetic studies converge to show that impulse control, the ability to delay gratification, and response inhibition are highly heritable (Barkley, 1997a; Bergen, Gardner, & Kendler, 2007; Dionne, Tremblay, Boivin, Laplante, & Perusse, 2003; Dunn & Plomin, 1990; Plomin, Caspi, Corley, Fulker, & DeFries, 1998; Polderman et al., 2006; Plomin, Owen, & McGuffin, 1994; Plomin, Reiss, Hetherington, & Howe, 1994; Rutter et al., 1997; Rietveld, Hudziak, Bartels, van Beijsterveldt, & Boomsma, 2003). Barkley (1997a), for example, notes that the heritability of ADHD and other “executive functions” frequently exceeds 0.85. More recent studies have found, however, that specific executive functions, many of which parallel Gottfredson and Hirschi’s (1990) concept of low self-control, are 100% heritable. Friedman et al.’s (2008) analysis of 582 individuals from 293 same-sex twin pairs in the Colorado Twin Study found that executive functions, such as response inhibition, task shifting, and updating working memory, was correlated because they were subsumed by a general factor that was virtually entirely heritable.

Further, neuroimaging studies document that underactivity in the regions of the prefrontal and orbital–frontal cortex correspond to deficits in self-control and emotional regulation (Bjork, Smith, Danube, & Hommer, 2007; Blakemore & Choudhury, 2006; Congdon & Canli, 2005; Eshel, Nelson, Blair, Pine, & Ernst, 2007; Galvan et al., 2006; Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover, & Casey, 2007; Lenroot & Giedd, 2006; Liston et al., 2006; Luna & Sweeney, 2004; Meyer-Lindenberg et al., 2006; Perez-Edgar et al., 2007; Rubia et al., 2006). In general, these studies link hypoactivity in the frontal cortex of the brain to behavioral dysinhibition, impulsivity, and self-regulatory deficiencies—hallmarks of low self-control.

Additionally, molecular genetic studies have documented evidence that genetic polymorphisms involved in the regulation and transportation of dopamine increase sensation seeking and a variety of impulse control problems (Beaver et al., 2007; Becker, Laucht, El-Faddagh, & Schmidt, 2005; El-Faddagh, Laucht, Maras, Vöhringer, & Schmidt, 2004; Faraone, Doyle, Mick, & Biederman, 2001; Floresco & Tse, 2007; Friedel, 2007; Grace, Floresco, Goto, & Lodge, 2007). Dopamine is an excitatory neurotransmitter expressed throughout the brain but is preferentially distributed in the ventral tegmental area (VTA; Floresco & Tse, 2007; Grace et al., 2007; Liston et al., 2006; O’Doherty, 2004). The VTA is strongly implicated in the etiology of addiction. Dopamine release occurs when stimuli are perceived as rewarding and in instances where an association has been made between a behavior and its consequent rewards.

sec.title: Parenting as a Source of Stress in an Adolescent’s Life
sec.p: Self-control is likely a biologically linked brain-based function. Even so, evidence from genetically informed studies also indicates that environmental stimuli have measurable influences for children with specific risk genotypes (Jaffee, Belsky, Harrington, Caspi, & Moffitt, 2006; Jaffee, Caspi, Moffitt, & Taylor, 2004; Jaffee & Price, 2007; Maes et al., 1999; Rutter et al., 1997). That is, youths who possess genotypes that make them more sensitive to stress-filled home environments may be more at risk for low self-control than for youths with other genotypes. Parent–offspring relationships may be an especially salient context to understand variability in self-control because parenting efforts often involve placing limits on youth behavior and activities, sometimes to the consternation of youth. This is especially true in adolescence, when parent–child conflict increases (Allison & Schultz, 2004). Efforts that substitute the judgment of the parent for that of the youth can generate conflict within parent–child dyads—conflict that could potentially spillover into the rest of the family (Patterson, 1982). This may be especially relevant in families where the behavior of the offspring creates conflict.

Regardless of the causal direction, numerous studies converge to show that stressful parent–child relationships are intertwined with a range of deleterious outcomes including delinquency, drug use, and criminal conduct (Farrington, 1991; Tarter et al., 1993; Vance, Bowen, Fernandez, & Thompson, 2002). Stressful parent–child relationships also account for variance in ADHD, in oppositional defiance disorder, and in conduct disorder. Burt, Krueger, McGue, and Iacono’s (2003) analysis of 808 twin pairs from the Minnesota Twin Study found that conflict, a proxy measure of stress, accounted for 33% of the covariation between these comorbid disorders. Conflict laden, stress-filled parent–child relationships, they found, were a ubiquitous aspect of family functioning in families with diagnosed youth.

These findings have recently been extended by contemporary, genetically informed studies. In a study of families (n = 720) with two or more children stratified by genetic relatedness, Feinberg, Button, Neiderhiser, Reiss, and Hetherington (2007) found that parental negativity and low parental warmth interacted with a youth’s genotype to produce either more or less antisocial behavior. At low levels of parental warmth, genetic factors accounted for 90% of the variance in antisocial behavior. Increasing levels of parental warmth reduced the influence of genetic factors to near zero. Moreover, Feinberg et al. also found that genetic factors explained a higher proportion of the variance in antisocial behavior of offspring when parental negativity exceeded average levels—strongly suggesting that youths are differentially affected by parental negativity. Substantive declines in genetic influences on antisocial behavior were found when parental negativity was below average levels. Feinberg et al. (2007, p. 464) concluded that “children with a genetically influenced temperamental style, such as a proclivity toward anger, may respond to harsh parenting with emotional and behavioral outbursts.”

The message from these studies is that an aversive parent–youth relationship may act as a liability for a range of adolescent problems. Even so, the influences of problematic adult–youth relationships are likely contingent on the genotype of the youth. Genetic influences may be one mechanism that distinguishes between youth in their levels of self-control, particularly when they are accompanied by relatively high levels of parental hostility. Our study uses these insights and examines how self-control in adolescence is conditioned by dopamine genotypes and maternal negativity. Unlike prior studies, which examined samples of twins or samples of genetically related individuals, we utilize a sample with direct measures of genes that prior research has found to be associated with low self-control.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: The present analysis uses data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health). The Add Health study was originally designed to explore how families, schools, friends, and communities impact the behaviors of youths (Harris et al., 2003). In order to achieve a nationally representative sample of adolescents in Grades 7 through 12, a multistage stratified sampling design was conducted. The primary sampling frame was composed of all high schools in the United States that included an 11th grade and had an enrollment of at least 30 students. From this sampling frame, a stratified random sample of 80 high schools was selected. In addition, a feeder school in each high school’s district was selected. Students enrolled at these schools were given an in-school survey that focused on the topics of family, health, and school. Over 90,000 questionnaires were completed. In order to collect more detailed information, a subsample was selected to participate in a series of in-home interviews. The first wave of the in-home subsample was selected by stratifying the school rosters by grade level and by sex, which resulted in the participation of 20,745 youths. In addition, the researchers asked that each child have one parent complete an in-home interview consisting of questions regarding their child, family, and relationships.

At present, the Add Health study includes three waves of data. The Wave 1, in-home interview data were collected between April and December 1995 when most of the respondents were between 11 and 19 years old. Twelve months later, the second wave of data was collected. The third wave of in-home interview data was collected between August 2001 and April 2002, when most of the participants were between the ages of 18 and 26 years.

The Add Health study also includes genetic data. During the third wave of data collection, respondents who reported at Wave 1 having a sibling or a co-twin were asked to provide a sample of their saliva for DNA testing. Individuals were then genotyped for five genes: DAT1, DRD2, DRD4, 5HTT, and MAOA. The analytic sample for this study is thus drawn from the restricted-use biological Add Health sample. It is composed of 1,494 individuals aged 12–18, at Wave 1. Cases were excluded from consideration if they did not meet the age constraints (12–18 and still living at home) and if they selected a race other than African American or Caucasian. Moreover, in situations where the subject reported being an monozygotic (MZ) twin, we randomly excluded one twin from the sample to avoid duplication of genotypes (Haberstick, 2007). The gender/race breakdown of the sample is 53% female (47% male) and 22% African American (78% Caucasian) and contains only those subjects with genetic information.

sec.title: Dopaminergic polymorphisms
sec.p: Before we discuss the coding of the dopamine genes, it is worthwhile to note that many genes are polymorphic—that is, they have different combinations. These versions, known as alleles, are inherited by offspring who receive one copy from their biological father and another copy from their biological mother. Each allele, moreover, may produce different proteins that will interact physiologically with other cells. Certain alleles are known as “risk alleles” because they have been associated with an increased risk for problems, be it a disease, a personality characteristic, or a behavior. We coded each of the dopamine genes in accordance with past research that identified which allele conferred the greatest risk. Offspring could receive zero (0) risk alleles, one (1) risk allele, or two (2) risk alleles.

We examine two genetic polymorphisms associated with the dopaminergic system. The first is a polymorphism found in the dopamine transporter gene DAT1. The variable was coded to reflect the number of 10R alleles possessed by each respondent (0, 1, 2). DAT1 is involved in the transportation of dopamine from the presynaptic neuron to the cellular membrane on the receiving dendrite. Variation in DAT1 is associated with alterations in the rate of dopamine transportation and reuptake and has been associated with novelty seeking (Bau et al., 2001), aggression (Chen et al., 2007), and violence (Guo, Roettger, & Shih, 2007).

The second dopaminergic polymorphism analyzed was DRD4. Consistent with prior research (Beaver et al., 2007), we classified subjects based on the number of alleles with repeat lengths of seven or greater. Alleles with less than seven repeats were coded as zero (0). The 7R allele has been associated with a range of clinical diagnoses and detrimental outcomes, including depression (Lopez-Leon et al., 2008), antisocial behavior (Beaver et al., 2007), and ADHD (El-Faddagh et al., 2004). Recent neuroimaging studies have found significant cortical thinning in the orbital–frontal cortex associated with the 7R allele, clearly implicating the 7R allele in deficits in self-control (Shaw et al., 2007).

sec.title: Low self-control
sec.p: The Add Health data contain limited measures of self-control. These measures, however, have been utilized previously by Perrone, Sullivan, Pratt, and Margaryan (2004) and more recently by Wright, Beaver, DeLisi, and Vaughn (2008) and were replicated for the current study. The measure of low self-control at Wave 1 was identical to the measure used at Wave 2 (r = .53). Items comprising these scales asked respondents whether they had problems keeping their mind focused, whether they had difficulty getting along with teachers, and whether the respondent had trouble paying attention in school. Higher values indicate lower levels of self-control (Wave 1 α = .63; Wave 2 α = .67). Prior research has found that the effects of self-control do not appear to be produced by differential measurement of self-control (Pratt & Cullen, 2000).

sec.title: Maternal negativity
sec.p: Maternal negativity reflects a global index of a difficult maternal–adolescent relationship. To measure maternal negativity, we used three identical adolescent self-report scales taken from Waves 1 and 2. Following the procedures of Wright et al. (2008), we factor analyzed the three adolescent self-report scales separately at Wave 1 and again at Wave 2. The results of the factor analyses indicated that the scales formed a single underlying factor at each wave, explaining 58% and 60% of the variance, respectively (r = .59). All scales were coded to reflect an increased risk for relationship problems. The items composing the scales are presented in Appendix A.

Scales used in the factor analysis included a 2-item measure of maternal attachment. This scale has been used repeatedly by scholars utilizing the Add Health data (Haynie, 2001; Schreck, Fisher, & Miller, 2004). These two items index how close the subject felt to their mother and the adolescent’s perception of how much their mother cared for them (α = .59/.68). The second scale assessed the degree of maternal rejection perceived by the adolescent. This scale tapped whether the adolescent’s mother was cold and withdrawn. It also assessed how satisfied the adolescent was with their relationship with their mother (α = .80/.83). Finally, a 9-item maternal involvement index was also used. Adolescents were asked whether they had participated (0 = no, 1 = yes) with their mother in any of nine events within the last 4 weeks. Adolescents, for example, were asked whether they had played a sport, went shopping, talked about personal problems, went to church, or talked about grades or school.

The measure of maternal negativity parallels domains assessed by Feinberg et al. (2007). High scores on the maternal negativity scale reflect adolescent perceptions of low maternal warmth, limited maternal involvement, and low maternal–offspring attachment. In this instance, we suspect that the dopamine genes will predict low self-control only at high levels of maternal negativity. “For researchers interested in identifying specific genes associated with antisocial behavior,” note Feinberg et al. (2007, p. 464) “… greater consistency of results can be obtained by limiting samples to individuals who have experienced elevated levels of parental negativity and/or low levels of parental warmth.” We therefore dichotomized the adversity scale into 0 = low maternal negativity and 1 = high maternal negativity. Of course, the choice of where to dichotomize the sample must be driven by a priori assumptions about the nature of the relationship as well as pragmatic considerations of sample size and statistical power. Prior research indicates that genetic effects are likely strongest at the upper end of the maternal negativity distribution (Plomin, 1995; Plomin, DeFries, McClearn, & Rutter, 1997), so the threshold was established at 1 standard deviation (SD) above the mean of maternal negativity.

Finally, we control for the effects of age, race (0 = White, 1 = Black), and sex (1 = male, 0 = female) in all regression analyses. We also control in each model for prior levels of low self-control and for prior levels of maternal negativity. This not only provides for a conservative test, it also reduces the likelihood that the results can be attributable to time-stable individual differences in self-control or in maternal negativity.

sec.title: Plan for Analysis
sec.p: We use ordinary least square (OLS) regression to assess the influence of the dopamine genes on low self-control measured at Wave 2. We present the results for the entire sample first, and then present the results for the low and high maternal negativity groups. Moreover, we assess the cumulative effects of DAT1 and DRD4 by summing the measures and entering the sum into the equations. We also assess the independent effects of DAT1 and DRD4 on low self-control as well as the interaction between DAT1 and DRD4 on low self-control. We examined the interaction between DRD4 and DAT1 by first mean centering each main effect and then multiplying the centered variables. Examination of the variance inflation factors and correlation matrices revealed no evidence of multicollinearity. Moreover, outlying cases were also examined. We found that only one case contained all four risk alleles. Elimination of this case had no influence on our results, so we retained the case.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 shows the findings of the OLS regression of low self-control on the cumulative, independent, and interactive measures of the dopamine genotypes. We find no evidence that these genotypes are statistically associated with low self-control in the overall sample. Being male, Black, and relatively younger were all associated with lower levels of self-control. Maternal negativity and low self-control, measured at Wave 1, were positively and significantly related to low self-control at Wave 2.

caption.p: OLS Regression Equations Predicting Low Self-Control (Wave 2) From the Cumulative, Independent, and Interactive Effects of DRD4 and DAT1 (Full Sample)

fn.p: Note. OLS = ordinary least square. The values within parentheses shows one-tailed test.

sec.p: The results presented in Table 2, however, reveal a different picture. First, none of the dopamine measures were associated with low self-control in the low maternal negativity categories. The only variables consistently associated with low self-control in the low maternal negativity groups were race, being Black, and the prior wave measure of low self-control.

caption.p: OLS Regression Equation Predicting Low Self-Control (Wave 2) From the Cumulative, Independent, and Interactive Effects of DRD4 and DAT1 by Maternal Negativity

sec.p: Examining the high maternal negativity categories, however, reveals a different pattern. All genotypic measures were significantly and positively related to low self-control in the high maternal negativity category. The cumulative dopamine measure was positively and significantly predictive of deficits in low self-control (β = .20). The dopamine measures also showed independent effects on low self-control in the high maternal negativity category (DRD4 and DAT1, β = .16). Moreover, the results in the interaction model revealed that the interaction between the genes was substantive and statistically significant (β = .21). We note that the associations between the DRD4 and DAT1 withstood controls for prior low self-control, prior maternal negativity, and the demographic variables.

The analyses provide evidence linking these risk genotypes to low levels of self-control. However, the influence of these genotypes appears dependent on the level of maternal negativity. The evidence thus suggests that genes in the dopaminergic system are associated with variation in low self-control in youths only when youths are embedded in aversive maternal relationships. This is the essence of a Gene × Environment interaction, and it strongly suggests that environmental influences have effects predominately on those most genetically susceptible.

We also draw attention to the multiplicative interaction between DAT1 and DRD4. Genes are thought to influence behavior and traits in complex ways, including interacting with other genes in their network. Our results show that these risk genotypes do indeed interact, but that the interaction is again conditioned by the level of maternal negativity.

Finally, numerous studies have found that self-control is relatively stable over time (Arneklev, Cochran, & Gainey, 1998). Because of this, we included a measure of prior low self-control in our models. While low self-control may be a relatively stable trait, our results show that aversive parent–adolescent relationships may still differentially affect those with the highest genetic risk for low self-control.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Individuals exposed to similar environmental stimuli, such as harsh and erratic parenting, often turn out substantially different. The majority of youth who encounter domestic abuse, neglect, or physical abuse, for example, do not go on to abuse their children or their spouse (McGloin & Widom, 2002; Widom & Brzustowicz, 2006). Yet the evidence is also clear that exposure to domestic violence and experiencing physical abuse and neglect elevates the risk of being an abuser later in life, as well as a host of other behavioral problems (Jaffee et al., 2002; Kim-Cohen, Caspi, Rutter, Tomá, & Moffitt, 2006; Widom & Brzustowicz, 2006).

Our study used this framework to examine the influence of maternal negativity on self-control in adolescents. Similar to the findings from other studies (Beaver, Ferguson, & Lynn-Whaley, 2010), these data revealed a positive correlation between maternal negativity and adolescent low self-control. Where our study departed from traditional criminological investigations, however, was in our employment of measured genotypes, and our investigation into the association between these genotypes, maternal negativity, and low self-control.

Results from this study provide evidence that variation in the dopaminergic subsystem conditions, modifies and interacts with maternal negativity and thus accounts for variation in self-control. In essence, results from this study help to explain why some individuals exposed to maternal negativity have problems with self-regulation while others, also exposed to maternal negativity, do not. Individuals with variants of the DAT1 and DRD4 genes were significantly more likely to manifest self-regulatory problems when these genotypes were accompanied by relatively high levels of maternal negativity.

Broadly speaking, we interpret our findings as evidence of a Gene × Environment interaction associated with low self-control. Gene × Environment interactions draw attention to the variability in human traits and behaviors between individuals exposed to similar, if not identical, environmental influences. From this line of reasoning, genetic differences between youth make some youth more, or less, susceptible, to environmental risk factors. Those at the highest level of genetic risk may be more strongly affected by difficult maternal relationships than those with less genetic risk. Our results provide evidence for this position and also show that the effect may be independent of an adolescent’s prior level of self-control.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: In closing, we briefly discuss the implications associated with this study. We begin by noting that Gottfredson and Hirschi’s (1990) general theory has enjoyed a broad array of empirical tests. Clearly, self-control is related to wide range of behaviors and life-style preferences. Even so, as echoed previously by Wright and Beaver (2005), it may be time to reformulate the general theory to incorporate explicitly genetic and biological influences as sources of variation in self-control. Continued tests of this aspect of the theory should recognize and, to the degree possible, incorporate genetic and biological factors.

Theories of family influences should also better specify the conditions under which parenting practices account for variation in offspring outcomes. Contemporary theories that highlight parenting as a source of variation in adolescent outcomes typically utilize broad concepts and make equally broad statements as to the effects of these concepts. For example, scholars argue that parents who are “warm and restrictive,” as opposed to “cold and permissive,” produce offspring with fewer behavioral problems (Collins, Maccoby, Steinberg, Hetherington, & Bornstein, 2000; Maccoby, 1992; Unnever, Cullen, & Agnew, 2006; Wilson & Herrnstein, 1985). Invariant constructs of family processes, however, cannot explain the substantial within-family variation found throughout social science research (Cohen, 1999; Harris, 1995, 1998). We offer three suggestions for future research.

First, criminologists interested in parenting influences should begin to grapple with the complexity that occurs when genetic and environmental forces correlate and interact. Findings from this study should allay fears that the inclusion of biology into an understanding of social processes will result in a form of reductionism that lacks scientific validity (Walsh, 1995). Understanding the role of genes and other biological processes highlights the mechanisms through which socialization processes generate their effects (Walsh, 2002, 2000).

Our second suggestion for future research on family functioning involves conceptualizing parental behaviors as a source of stress. Although an abundance of animal and human literature on organism responses to environmental stressors exists, it remains largely ignored in criminology (see, however, Agnew, 1992). This literature includes experimental and controlled studies into the neural, neuroendocrine, and physiological responses to real and perceived stress. Findings from this corpus of research shed light on the mechanisms linking sources of stress to individual differences, and they provide empirical specification in place of theoretical assumptions.

Third, while our research was not a test of hypotheses drawn from Gottfredson and Hisrchi’s theory of low self-control, it is clear that our results have implications for the general theory. As these and other data reveal, self-control is likely a trait under modest to strong genetic influence. Because of this, self-control is likely relatively stable over long periods of the life course. However, relative stability should not be confused with absolute stability. Features of the immediate environment, such as negative parenting, may still influence behavioral reactions rooted in self-control. In this sense, negative parenting may not cause low self-control in children and adolescents, but it may exacerbate preexisting problems with self-control.

In practical terms, our results also speak to why parental interventions, or interventions that change how parents act and react to their adolescents, sometimes show positive effects while at other times they show little to no effect. Changing parental strategies may, on the whole, benefit most children in the family, but it may not affect all children equally. Children, even in homes that are highly dysfunctional, are often unique in their traits, behaviors, and sensitivities. Intervention specialists should take care to notice differences between children and to address their unique needs.

sec.title: Description of Variables and Scales
sec.p: Maternal Negativity: Factor constructs derived by the following scales:
Maternal Attachment (items reverse coded)

Scale created by summing the following items:
How close do you feel to your mother?
How much do you think your mother cares about you?
Maternal Rejection (items reverse coded)
Scale created by summing the following items:

list-item.p: Most of the time, your mother is warm and loving toward you
When you do something wrong that is important, your mother talks about with you and helps you understand why it is wrong
You are satisfied with the way you and your mother communicate with each other
Overall, you are satisfied with your relationship with your mother
Maternal Involvement (items coded to reflect less involvement)
Index created by summing the following items:
Have you and your mother ________ in the last four weeks?
Went shopping
Played a sport
Went to church
Talked about life
Went to a museum, play, concert, movie, or sporting event
Talked about personal problems
Talked about school work or grades
Talked about other things you are doing in school
Worked on a school project
Low Self-Control (Wave 1 and Wave 2)
Scale created by summing the following items:
You feel like you are doing everything just about right
How often have you had trouble getting along with teachers?
How often have you had trouble paying attention in school?
How often have you had trouble getting your homework done?
How often have you had trouble getting along with other students?

fn.p: This research uses data from Add Health, a program project directed by Kathleen Mullan Harris and designed by J. Richard Udry, Peter S. Bearman, and Kathleen Mullan Harris at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and funded by grant P01-HD31921 from the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, with cooperative funding from 23 other federal agencies and foundations. Special acknowledgment is due Ronald R. Rindfuss and Barbara Entwisle for assistance in the original design. Information on how to obtain the Add Health data files is available on the Add Health website (http://www.cpc.unc.edu/addhealth). No direct support was received from grant P01-HD31921 for this analysis.
The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
